ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Polarization-independent broadband terahertz chiral metamaterials on flexible substrate

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: A THz band-reject filter is designed based on chiral four-fold rotational symmetry metamaterial. This filter was fabricated by laser micro-lens array lithography and characterized by terahertz time-domain spectroscopy. The resonant frequencies at different twist angles are almost the same, which demonstrates the polarization independence of the structure. The electric field distribution is simulated to explain the physics mechanism behind the polarization independence. By stacking multiple metamaterial layers together, a THz broadband reject filter at a bandwidth of 0.461 THz is experimentally achieved.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: Terahertz radiation (0.1–10 THz), which lies between the microwave and infrared bands across the electromagnetic (EM) spectrum, has attracted great research attention due to successfully developed efficient terahertz sources and detectors during the last decade [1, 2]. Various applications in the THz frequency regime, such as THz spectroscopy [3], imaging systems [4–6], communication [7], cloaking devices [8], and chemical sensing [9, 10], have been widely studied. Metamaterials [11–26] constructed by sub-wavelength metallic structures are artificially and flexibly engineered to realize unique functions, such as modulators, absorbers, and filters in the THz range. The split ring resonator (SRR) structure has been commonly used due to its strong EM response in the designed frequency regime. However, the SRR-based metamaterials show strong polarization dependence [20–22]. To solve this issue, a few metamaterials were designed based on rotational symmetry geometries, such as fishnets [24] and elliptical nanodisk arrays [25].

Chiral metamaterials have attracted considerable research attention due to their exotic properties, such as giant optical activity, circular dichroism, and negative refraction [27–29]. Similar to conventional metamaterials, chiral metamaterials require strong resonances to get chirality [30]. Loss associated with the resonance can be used to design filters based on chiral metamaterials. However, polarization independence is a key requirement for filtering unpolarized sources [31].

A novel polarization-independent band-reject THz filter based on chiral four-fold rotational symmetry geometry is proposed in this paper. The polarization-independent property is demonstrated by changing the twist angle of the patterns. By analyzing the electric field distribution, the physics behind the polarization independence is studied. To increase the bandwidth, four layers of the chiral metamaterials with mutual twisted geometries were stacked together as a new multi-layer chiral metamaterial.

Section1.Heading: Design of the polarization-independent band-reject filter
Section1.Para:
A chiral metamaterial was designed, as shown in Fig. 1a. This chiral structure was chosen due to its four-fold rotational symmetry, which can lead to polarization independence. It was fabricated on 100 μm thick polyethylene naphthalate (PEN) films by laser micro-lens array (MLA) lithography. The PEN films enable flexible applications on non-planar surfaces, allowing new potential applications. It can be easily wrapped around a cylinder with a diameter smaller than 1 cm to make cloaking devices. More than 10000 patterns were exposed simultaneously by the laser MLA lithography. MLA at a pitch size of 100 μm was used in this experiment, which defines the period of the metamaterial unit cell as p=100 μm. The sample substrates were firstly coated with 1.5 μm of Microposit S1813 positive tone photoresist and baked on a hot plate for 1 min at 110 °C before they were exposed by a Ti:sapphire second harmonic generation femtosecond laser (Spectra Physics Tsunami, Mode 3960, λ=400 nm, τ=100 fs, repetition rate=82 MHz) [23]. A 200 nm copper (Cu) film was deposited on the samples and patterned by lift-off. As shown in Fig. 1a, the metallic line width is defined as w=3 μm. The length of a spiral arm was fixed at 2a=60 μm. This chiral resonator structure was used as the fundamental SRR unit cell for all the subsequent analyses. Characterization was carried out by a terahertz time domain spectroscopy (THz–TDS) system in transmission mode under nitrogen environment. The normally incident THz wave is polarized with its electric field parallel to the y axis. The transmission spectra were normalized against the reference spectrum measured with the substrate in the same nitrogen environment. Finite-difference time-domain (FDTD) simulation was carried out. A periodic boundary was chosen to reproduce the chiral metamaterial array. In the simulation, the grid spacing is set as 5 μm×5 μm×5 μm for the free space and substrate, and 0.5 μm×0.5 μm×0.1 μm for the metal patterns. The real part of the permittivity ε and the loss tangent of PEN were set as 2.56 and 0.003 over the frequency of interest [22] and the metal copper with conductance 5.8×107 S/m is chosen [26]. The polarization direction of a normally incident linear plane wave is along the y axis. Figure 1b shows simulated and measured transmission spectra for the chiral THz metamaterial. It is clear that the simulated resonant dip is at 0.953 THz while the measured one is at 1.004 THz. The full-width at half-maximum (FWHM) of the resonant dip is 0.290 THz (from 0.834 to 1.124 THz) in the experiment and 0.271 THz (from 0.816 to 1.087 THz) in the simulation. Their slight deviations are due to material parameters and fabrication inaccuracy of the metallic line width (±200 nm for our laser MLA lithography). The numerical simulation and measured results show a reasonable agreement and a band-reject filter can be realized by the chiral four-fold rotational symmetry metamaterial.

To investigate the polarization independence, the chiral metamaterial was twisted at an angle of θ around its symmetry center (point O in Fig. 2a) in anticlockwise direction referred to the polarization of incident light (y axis), as shown in Fig. 2a. The chiral metamaterial pattern was twisted from 0 to 75 degrees at a step of 15 degrees, and its resonance responses at all twist angles are compared. Attributed to laser MLA lithography, the samples can be flexibly fabricated with a simple change of programming design. Figure 2 shows the microscopic images of different chiral metamaterials being fabricated at a twist angle θ of 15, 30, 45, 60, and 75 degrees. Simulated and experimental resonance frequencies at different twist angles are summarized in Fig. 2g. Referred to the resonant frequency at θ=0, the maximum resonant frequency difference at other twist angles is less than 3.7 % (for simulation) and 9 % (for experiment). It is polarization insensitive with a slight difference of resonant frequency, which is due to the coupling among the unit cells [32]. The separation distance r (see Figs. 2b to 2f) is defined as the minimum distance between the neighboring tips of two spiral arms (in the next section, our simulation results show that the electric fields are concentrated on the tips). It changes with twisting, which leads to coupling change and resonant frequency shift. Without twisting (θ=0), r is about 40 μm. The resonant frequency blue shift is shown at a twist angle θ of 15 degrees while r is about 60 μm (see Fig. 2b), which is larger than that at θ=0 degrees. When θ continuously increases, r becomes smaller and the blue shift decreases. At θ=45 degrees, r becomes the minimum at about 15 μm (see Fig. 2d) and the maximum red shift of the resonant frequency is reached. When θ>45 degrees, r increases while the twist angle increases and the deviation of the resonant frequency decreases. Our further simulation shows that the resonant frequency difference can be reduced to 1.1 % at a larger period of p=120 μm.

To understand the physics behind polarization independence, the electric field distribution at the resonant frequency for twist angles θ=0, 15, 30, 45, 60, and 75 degrees was simulated, as shown in Fig. 3. It is obvious that the electric field is mostly concentrated at the tips of the spiral arms. Meanwhile, the electric field distribution is center symmetric to the twisting center. The resonance can be classified into two components, as shown in Fig. 3a: one is along the direction of R1 and the other along the direction of R2. We use the peak electric field at the tip to characterize the intensity of resonance in our analysis. For θ=0, the resonance along R1 is strong with 48 times enhancement referred to the incident light but the resonance along R2 is weak with 18 times enhancement. When the twist angle θ increases, the resonance along R1 becomes weaker and reduces to almost zero at 60 degrees (see Fig. 3e). At the same time the resonance along R2 becomes stronger and reaches 67 times enhancement at θ=45 degrees. The energy is redistributed between the resonances along R1 and R2 as the twist angle changes. Since R1 and R2 are of the same design, they have same EM response, which leads to the same resonant frequency. Therefore, no matter how energy redistributes, the resonant frequency does not change a lot.

Section1.Heading: Broadband multi-layer chiral metamaterials
Section1.Para:
To improve the bandwidth of the filter, a series of metamaterials were stacked together by the same method as in Ref. [22]. The effect of adding additional layers on the overall resonance response was investigated to determine the optimal number of layers for constructing a broadband filter. It was determined from previous studies that the interlayer interaction is not significant, as the 100 μm interlayer distance is greater than the induced electromagnetic field attenuation length of the metamaterials [33, 34]. The four layers of PEN film with the same chiral patterns were stacked together as shown in Fig. 4a. Figure 4b shows the resonance bands at different numbers of layers with the same chiral metamaterial without twisting pattern on each layer. The single layer of chiral metamaterial (θ=0) has a bandwidth of about 0.271 THz. When the number of layers increases to four, the reject band is increased to about 0.507 THz (from 0.667 to 1.174 THz). It can be observed that the resonance band is widened with additional layers. However, as the number of layers increases, the loss in the dielectric materials increases and a Fabry–Perot effect among different layers occurs. These effects can result in higher absorption, which leads to lower transmission. Considering the bandwidth and absorption loss simultaneously, a four-layer configuration was chosen to construct the broadband filter.

To further demonstrate the polarization independence over a broad band, chiral metamaterials were also adopted to construct a polarization-independent broadband filter. A twist sample is designed as four-layer metamaterials at a twist angle of 0, 22.5, 45, and 67.5 degrees (see Fig. 5a) to compare with normal four-layer metamaterials without twisting (see Fig. 4a). If the single-layer metamaterial is polarization dependent, these two metamaterials should have different EM responses. In fact, the simulated transmission spectra of the two metamaterials are almost the same, as shown in Fig. 5b. The twisted one was fabricated by directly stacking four layers with different twist angles together. As shown in Fig. 5b, a broadband absorption from 0.719 to 1.180 THz can be made. The FWHM of the sample is 0.461 THz, about 1.6 times the measured bandwidth of single-layer chiral metamaterial of 0.290 THz. Compared with the simulated reject band of 0.507 THz, the experimental and simulated results show good agreement.

Section1.Heading: Conclusions
Section1.Para: A new polarization-independent THz band-reject filter was designed based on a four-fold rotational symmetry chiral metamaterial on a flexible substrate, which was fabricated by laser MLA lithography and characterized by THz–TDS. The polarization independence was demonstrated: there is no big difference of resonant frequencies when twisting the patterns. To explain the physical mechanism of this polarization independence, the electric field distribution was simulated and analyzed. The resonant frequency does not change due to energy redistribution in twisting of two resonant modes which have the same design. To increase the bandwidth, the metamaterials were stacked together layer by layer. By stacking four layers of flexible THz chiral metamaterials with different twist angles together, a broadband filter at a bandwidth of 0.461 THz (increased from 0.290 THz for single-layer chiral metamaterial) was realized experimentally.
